Ι suspect that you did not altogether approve what was disapproved by your intimates (excellent men, I admit, but unversed in pohtics), that I carried a resolution conferring upon Caesar the right of a J oyous Entry.‘² For myself-—but perhaps I am at fault, only I am not the man to take the highest pleasure in my own achievements—I do not think that in this war I ever had a sounder idea ; the reason for this I must not disclose, lest I should make an impression of foresight rather than of grati- tude.—I arn labouring this point too much3 so let us turn to something else. I had honours conferred upon D. Brutus and upon L. Plancus. Theirs are indeed noble natures that heed the call of glory ; but the Senate too shows discretion, in that it offers whatever inducement (consistent with honour) it thinks will serve in each particular case to win a man to the service of the state. But you take me to task about Lepidus : we first set up a statue in his honour οΠ the Speakers' Platform, then we cast it down. We made an effort to recall him from his madness by honouring him. The infatuation of that fluffiest of fellows proved too strong for our precau- tions; even so, less harm was done in setting up Lepidus' statue than good in casting it down. Enough has been said about honours. Now I must 10

make a few remarks about punishment ; for I have often discerned from your letters that you wish to be given credit for leniency in regard to those whom you have overmastered in war. I consider indeed that your wisdom is unfailing; yet I believe that to remit punishment for crime (for that is what “ pardoning '’ amounts to), however passable it may be on another occasion, is utterly ruinous in this war.
